reviewText: this would have been a 5 star video for the filming, staging & performance, but has anyone noticed that the vocals are barely audible & mixed way down low in the mix?  that's a shame because Belinda Carlile's singing is one of the keys of the group's sound, but here it is not front & centered as it should be.
summary: what happened to the vocal mix here?

reviewText: Never having seen the Go-Go's live, I wanted to see just who was making this fun American-born rock and roll.  It is a wonderful performance, but I can't pretend to be an expert on music, so trust the other reviews.  One tip - some complaints have appeared about the disappointing sound.  My DVD also has that defect on the 5.1 DTS and Dolby 5.1 settings, Belinda's vocals are muddy.  Don't fret - use the 2 channel stereo setting, and all is well.  If your DVD player has equilization settings - look for EQ on your remote - try a setting such as "live" or "rock".  It really rocks, it really sounds great, and the ladies in the band can really play their instruments and write catchy tunes!
summary: The girls answer for the Beach Boys!
Title: N/A

reviewText: Maybe it's part of a mid-life crisis (I'm 47 as I write this), but I'm rediscovering groups that I knew a little about when I was younger, and am introducing myself to more of their music.  Considering I only was familiar with three of their songs ("Vacation", my favorite "Our Lips Are Sealed", and of course "We've Got The Beat"), this was a nice introduction to more of the Go Gos songs, and it did not disappoint.Charlotte, Belinda, Kathy, and Jane all seemed to be having as much fun singing as the audience (and myself) enjoyed listening.  The one drawback to this video:  Gina Shock (the drummer), who I consider the prettiest, did not seem to be enjoying herself.  It may be she was just focusing on her playing instead of smiling, but she looked angry to me.  (Just my personal opinion.)One concern both my wife and I have is the dress (or more specifically the lack thereof) of women in the public eye.  We both were impressed by how modest the women were, especially considering it was taped in 2001.  Kathy Valentine (the bassist) did wear a miniskirt, but that is better than a lot of what one sees nowadays.Let me conclude my review with a warning.  If you watch this video, you might have the same problem I had, wanting to break out suddenly and sing "We've Got the Beat", which I couldn't get out of my mind.

reviewText: I saw the Go-Go's in 1984 after "Talk Show" was released and loved them then - upon seeing this DVD, i enjoy them just as much - the 1984 concert in Maryland was about the most enjoyable concert I have been to and this DVD shows me they're still just as much fun.  Belinda sings alot better than she did then, of course, and the other three sing louder than they did then, obviously due to more self confidence in their vocal abilities - the new keyboard touches in some of the songs were nice but I betcha Charlotte is probably nervous on stage behind the keyboards - well, other than "Head Over Heels."  The fly on the wall piece is good, especially Gina and her cell phone.
summary: Still Rockin' After How Many Years?
Title: N/A

reviewText: I thought "God Bless the Go-Go's" was one of the best albums of 2001 and a really great rock `n' roll album.  I thought that Belinda Carlisle had never sounded better, mainly because of the wonderful harmonies provided by Jane Wiedlin.  I thought Charlotte Caffey was continuing to build on the song writing talent she displayed on "Talk Show" (and on her one album with the Graces, "Perfect View").  Paul Q. Kolderie and Sean Slade were the main producers and mixers on the album and apparently deserve a lot of credit because the Go-Go's never sounded better.  The main reason this concert video of the "Go-Go's Live in Central park" is so disappointing is that the sound mix is awful, deplorable, utterly disappointing, and really, really bad.  Slightly better than the rehearsal tapes from the early days that popped up on "Return to the Valley of the Go-Go's."  For the most part the instruments overwhelm the vocals from start to finish in this concert.  I have seen several live performances by the Go-Go's over the years, and Belinda Carlisle is never as good on stage as she is in the studio, but she does not even stand a chance on this one.The concert is a mix between the new (seven tracks from the new album) and the requisite hits from yesterday ("Vacation," "We Got the Beat," and "Our Lips Are Sealed").  The "Talk Show" album, which represented the original great leap forward by the band from punk group to pop rockers, is woefully under-represented ("Head Over Heels" still starts the gig), but that is understandable since the group's previous concert video was for the tour for that album.  Again, the new songs, which rely more on the vocal harmonies (e.g., "Unforgiven," "Apology"), suffer because of the sound problems.Fortunately the DVD is redeemed, somewhat, by the over 30-minutes of behind-the-scenes footage which show the band getting ready for the gig while their fans get all revved up to party.  The person who ends up impressing you the most in this footage is Gina Schock, not only because she is all business drumming away on stage, but because she emerges as the most articulate member talking about the Go-Go's then and now (ironic, since she is the only one of the group who never sings and remains silent throughout the concert, although she is working seriously on her wad of gum).  Finally, I do want to point out that "Apology" is far and away the best song for which Kathy Valentine has ever been listed as lead writer.  In the end "The Go-Go's Live in Central Park" is for the true Go-Go groupie, who will endure the less than adequate sound just to see the gals rockin' and rollin' again.
summary: Looks 10 Sound 3 for the Go-Go's Concert in Central Park

reviewText: In my library of music videos, I have the Go-Go's 1981 VHS music video "Totally Go-Go's!"  It was their first video that accompanied the release of their first album.  The Go-Go's played a concert at a Los Angeles high school.  The concert was full of energy and featured their hits from their debut album with backstage behind-the-scene footage.Fast forward 20 years and it's the Go-Go's "Live in Central Park."  The girls have aged wonderfully.  Their performance has the same energy and excitement as in their first video, but "Live in Central Park" is much, much better.  I was totally enthralled by this live concert DVD.  The high quality sound and footage makes you feel as if you're right there.  The selection of songs is outstanding - a mixture of their past hits and from their latest CD "God Bless the Go-Go's."I truly regret never having seen the Go-Go's perform live in concert.  Hopefully, I will get a chance.  If not, watching "Live in Central Park" will be the next best thing.  The Go-Go's are awesome!  This DVD is awesome!

reviewText: i like the GoGos enough to have a greatest hits cd so thought to ck this dvd out and have mixed thoughts. upon listening to the performance i could barely hear Belindas vocals so after the hits when they start playing the new songs i couldnt make out one from the other. all sounded the same as i couldnt hear the vocals well. the crowd was ok but there were times after the group would finish n i barely heard applause and then one audience member shouted 'i love you Belinda!' n she said 'you dont even know me' and had a really snide look on her face that i think others detected because then audience members through the rest of the show were throwing dirty underwear (jane commented on it) at Belinda on stage. so i'm not sure what to think. and then i thought well maybe Belinda is just having an off day as the 'fun' looked 'forced' on stage and i watched the lil doc where the girls r in the van going to the venue and Belinda is pissed off the whole time and tbh, i wouldnt want to b around her. so i guess i have the memories of the hits in my head and if you find the dvd for a couple bucks to hear the old songs i guess would b worth it but skip the doc on the girls as most seem uptight and not the 'fun' that i was expecting.

reviewText: This is a great concert DVD for fans of the "Go-Go's". The band is in fine form and they look like they're really having fun on stage. The picture and 5.1 DTS sound are really amazing, but the volume for the vocals could have been turned up a bit. The sound seems to fluctuate up and down on some of the songs. The video image from Image Entertainment  is quite impressive and it makes this DVD enjoyable to watch.The ladies all look great and the music is really tight as they belt out 18 songs one after another. Gina Schock's drumming really stands out in this live performance and its the glue that holds it all together. She sits quietly behind her drum kit chewing gum and her playing seems so effortless. The bonus extras are fun and great to watch. This concert DVD is a must for any "Go-Go's" fan new or old.DVD Tracks Include:1. Head Over Heels2. Skidmarks on My Heart3. Stuck in My Car4. How Much More5. Apology6. Vacation7. Insincere8. Sonic Superslide9. Automatic10. Automatic Rainy Day11. This Town12. Unforgiven13. Beatnik Beach14. Our Lips Are Sealed15. La La Land16. We Got the Beat17. Throw Me a Curve18. I Wanna Be Sedated

reviewText: The Go-Go's Live in Central Park, is a fun and entertaining performance recorded in 2001, very shortly after the release of God Bless the Go-Go's, the band's first new album in seventeen years.  The concert is both a journey back to the band's heyday in the 80's, and a look forward with their new music.  The eighteen song performance, features a mix of classic material and eight selections from their new album.  Although the new material is perhaps a bit edgier and more mature, the music still has the same classic Go-Go's sound, resulting in a pretty cohesive show.The large outdoor stage in New York's Central Park is a neat venue for the band, who kick things off with 'Head Over Heels', featuring Charlotte Caffey on keyboards.  It doesn't take long for singer Belinda Carlisle to kick off her heels and begin roaming around the stage, making keeping a spotlight on her a challenge.  Gina Schock drives the beat hard on the drums, while guitarist Jane Weidlin and bass player Kathy Valentine, keep things jumping.  The band seems to be having a great time.  The infusion of a lot of unfamiliar new material, may cause the crowd to be a bit subdued, but enthusiasm builds during the older material.  With 'This Town', 'Vacation', 'Skidmarks On My Heart', 'Beatnik Beach', 'Our Lips Are Sealed' and "We Got the Beat', the Go-Go's deliver the classic material people came to her.  However the new songs like 'Apology', 'Insincere', 'Stuck in My Car', 'La La Land', and 'Sonic Superslide' are great as well.  The ladies certainly rocked hard in this performance, which is a mere 65 minutes, with the finale being a cover of The Ramones 'I Wanna Be Sedated'.The video is wonderfully clear, if the editing cuts were just delayed a few seconds, the concert would be much more enjoyable.  The audio mix is pretty good, with vocals being mostly up front and only occasionally drowned out.  The drums are kicking all the time, and the guitars have some cool industrial dirtiness, but as is evident in Kathy's solo passage in 'Head Over Heels', the bass needs to be cranked up.The extras are fun stuff, including video shot the day of the performance of the band members getting their makeup done, goofing around on the way to Central Park, and then getting ready to take the stage.  We see that Jane is very outgoing, while Belinda is the quiet one, at least on this day.  And there is a four minute interview piece with the band, discussing their comeback and some of the new songs.  A little more depth interview would have been nice.  After so long, fans might be interested in things like what's been happening since the split, why and how did they reunite, and how do the members feel about the band and their music after recording the new album?  Was there any special story behind the Central Park concert?  What about additional follow up regarding the 2001 comeback?Formed in 1978, with a punk/new wave influence, The Go-Go's were one of the first all female bands in rock to perform their own material.  In a short hyper-productive period, the band produced the albums Beauty and the Beat (1981), Vacation (1982), and Talk Show (1984).  Unfortunately, problems within the group led to Jane Weidlin's departure in 1984, stalling the Go-Go's career.  The members pursued their individual paths, with Belinda Carlisle finding the biggest commercial success.  The original lineup reunited a few times over the years, recording some new material for the retrospective Return to the Valley of the Go-Go's (1994).  But it was not until 2001, that the original members would reunite to record God Bless the Go-Go's, a great album which seasoned by mature song writing, updates the classic Go-Go's sound.  At the moment, the CD is very inexpensive, so check it out.
Title: N/A
